abstract.t: This document defines the AI Boundary Declaration Protocol (AIBDP), a machine-readable manifest format for declaring acceptable and prohibited uses of content by AI systems. AIBDP enables content originators to express consent boundaries for training, indexing, generation, and other AI engagement modes via a standardized JSON manifest hosted at /.well-known/aibdp.json. It supports enforcement through HTTP status codes such as 430 (Consent Required) and provides a foundation for consent-aware web architecture.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: AI systems routinely ingest, process, and regenerate web content without explicit consent from originators. Existing mechanisms like robots.txt were designed for crawling and indexing, not for the nuanced boundaries required in the age of generative AI. AIBDP addresses this gap by providing:

list.t: Declarative consent framework for AI-specific uses (training, generation, summarization, etc.)
Standardized manifest format (JSON) at a well-known URI
Integration with HTTP enforcement mechanisms (e.g., status code 430)
Support for federated and self-sovereign publishing
Optional cryptographic verification (COSE signatures)

section.t: AIBDP is designed to work alongside existing protocols (robots.txt, HTTP headers, TDM Reservation Protocol) while providing granular control over AI-specific boundary declarations.

section.title: Terminology
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119.
Additionally, this document uses the following terms:

list.t: Any computational system that processes content for training, inference, generation, or augmentation purposes, including but not limited to large language models (LLMs), computer vision systems, and retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) systems.
The entity publishing content and declaring usage boundaries via AIBDP.
The AIBDP JSON document hosted at /.well-known/aibdp.json.
A declared permission or prohibition for a specific AI usage mode.
The set of resources to which a policy applies (file patterns, paths, etc.).

section.title: Protocol Overview
section.t: AIBDP operates through the following mechanism:

list.t: Content originators publish a JSON manifest at /.well-known/aibdp.json
AI systems retrieve and parse the manifest before accessing content
Systems respect declared boundaries or indicate inability to comply
Servers MAY enforce boundaries by responding with HTTP 430 (Consent Required) when violations are detected
Manifests MAY include cryptographic signatures for integrity verification

section.title: Relationship to robots.txt
section.t: AIBDP complements robots.txt rather than replacing it:

list.t: robots.txt controls crawling and indexing behavior
AIBDP declares boundaries for AI-specific uses (training, generation, etc.)
When both exist, AI systems SHOULD honor both
AIBDP provides finer-grained control for modern AI use cases

section.title: Discovery and Caching
section.t: AI systems SHOULD:

list.t: Fetch /.well-known/aibdp.json before initial content access
Cache manifests according to "expires" field
Respect "canonical_uri" for cross-domain manifests
Re-fetch on HTTP 430 responses with Link header to manifest

section.title: Manifest Format
section.t: AIBDP manifests are JSON documents conforming to the following structure:

list.t: String indicating protocol version (e.g., "0.2")
String with contact URI (mailto:, https:, etc.) for policy inquiries
Object containing policy declarations (see Section 4.2)

section.title: Policy Declarations
section.t: The "policies" object contains keys for different AI usage modes:

list.t: training: Use of content for model training
indexing: Building searchable indices
summarization: Generating summaries or abstracts
question_answering: RAG systems responding to queries
generation: Synthetic content creation based on corpus
fine_tuning: Specialized model adaptation
embedding: Creating vector representations
commercial_training: Training for commercial AI products

section.t: Each policy MAY contain:

list.t: REQUIRED. One of: "allowed", "refused", "conditional", "encouraged"
Array of strings describing requirements when status is "conditional"
Array of path patterns this policy applies to
Array of exception objects with path, status, and note
Human-readable explanation of policy
Suggested alternative approaches
Authoritative location of this manifest
ISO 8601 timestamp when manifest should be re-fetched
Link to human-readable policy document
Object describing what AI systems this manifest addresses
Object with provisions for specific use cases (academic research, education, etc.)
Object describing enforcement mechanisms
Object with authorship, creation date, related standards
COSE signature object for cryptographic verification (see Section 6)

section.title: Example Manifest
Path Scoping
section.t: Policies MAY specify scope using path patterns:

list.t: Exact paths: "/about.html"
Directory wildcards: "/blog/**" (all files under /blog/)
File patterns: "/docs/*.pdf"
Special value "all" applies to entire domain

section.t: When multiple policies apply to the same resource, the most restrictive policy SHOULD take precedence unless exceptions are specified.

section.title: Cryptographic Verification
section.t: Manifests MAY include a "signature" field containing a COSE (RFC 9052) signature:

list.t: Ensures manifest integrity and authenticity
Prevents tampering by intermediaries (CDNs, proxies)
Enables audit trails for consent verification

section.t: AI systems capable of signature verification SHOULD validate signatures when present and reject manifests with invalid signatures.

section.title: Enforcement Integration
section.t: AIBDP is designed to integrate with HTTP enforcement mechanisms:

section.title: HTTP 430 Consent Required
section.t: Servers detecting AIBDP violations SHOULD respond with HTTP 430 (see draft-jewell-http-430-consent-required):
section.artwork:
HTTP/1.1 430 Consent Required Content-Type: application/json Link: <https://example.org/.well-known/aibdp.json>; rel="blocked-by-consent" Retry-After: 86400
{ "error": "AI usage boundaries declared in AIBDP manifest not satisfied", "manifest": "https://example.org/.well-known/aibdp.json", "violated_policy": "training", "required_conditions": ["Attribution required", "Non-commercial use only"] }

section.title: Detection Mechanisms
section.t: Servers MAY detect AI systems through:

list.t: User-Agent headers (e.g., "GPTBot", "Claude-Web")
Request patterns (high-volume sequential access)
Missing consent headers when required
Client identification via API keys or authentication

section.title: Consent Headers
section.t: AI systems MAY include headers indicating consent compliance:
section.artwork: GET /article.html HTTP/1.1 Host: example.org User-Agent: ResearchBot/1.0 AI-Purpose: indexing AI-Consent-Reviewed: https://example.org/.well-known/aibdp.json AI-Consent-Conditions: attribution,non-commercial

section.title: Federated and Cross-Domain Policies
section.t: AIBDP supports federated scenarios:

section.title: Canonical URIs
section.t: The "canonical_uri" field enables:

list.t: CDN-hosted content pointing to origin manifest
Mirrored sites sharing a single policy
Federated identity systems declaring unified boundaries

section.t: AI systems encountering "canonical_uri" SHOULD fetch and respect the referenced manifest.

section.title: Multi-Domain Policies
section.t: Organizations managing multiple domains MAY:

list.t: Host a single canonical manifest referenced by all domains
Use DNS TXT records to indicate manifest location
Employ cryptographic signatures to verify cross-domain authenticity

section.title: Privacy Considerations
section.t: AIBDP manifests are public declarations. Implementers should consider:

list.t: Manifests SHOULD NOT contain private information
Contact information SHOULD be organizational, not personal
Detailed scope patterns MAY reveal site structure
Manifests do not track or log AI system access (use server logs for auditing)

section.t: The protocol itself does not create new privacy risks beyond existing web publication models.

section.title: Manifest Integrity
section.t: Servers SHOULD:

list.t: Serve manifests over HTTPS to prevent tampering
Use COSE signatures for high-value content
Validate JSON schema to prevent malformed manifests
Set appropriate cache headers to balance freshness and load

section.title: Denial of Service
section.t: AI systems fetching manifests SHOULD:

list.t: Cache manifests according to "expires" field
Implement exponential backoff on errors
Respect Retry-After headers
Limit manifest size (RECOMMENDED: 1MB maximum)

section.title: Spoofing and Substitution
section.t: Attackers might attempt to:

list.t: Serve fake manifests via DNS hijacking (mitigated by HTTPS + signatures)
Inject permissive manifests via MITM (mitigated by HTTPS)
Exploit manifest parsing vulnerabilities (mitigated by schema validation)

section.t: Implementations MUST validate manifest structure and SHOULD verify signatures when present.

section.title: Enforcement Limitations
section.t: AIBDP is a declarative protocol, not a technical enforcement mechanism:

list.t: Non-compliant AI systems MAY ignore manifests
Detection of violations requires active monitoring
Legal or reputational consequences provide primary enforcement
HTTP 430 responses signal boundary violations but cannot prevent initial access

section.t: AIBDP establishes procedural clarity for consent, not cryptographic access control.

section.title: Extensibility
section.t: AIBDP is designed for future extension:

list.t: New policy keys MAY be added for emerging AI use cases
Implementations SHOULD ignore unknown fields (forward compatibility)
Version negotiation via "aibdp_version" field
Custom fields SHOULD use reverse-DNS prefixing (e.g., "com.example.custom_policy")

section.t: Future versions MAY define:

list.t: Dynamic policy updates via Server-Sent Events or WebSockets
Per-user consent declarations for authenticated systems
Tiered access levels based on AI system reputation
Integration with decentralized identity systems (DIDs)

section.title: For Content Publishers
section.t: Publishers implementing AIBDP SHOULD:

list.t: Define clear AI usage boundaries aligned with organizational values
Create manifest at /.well-known/aibdp.json with appropriate policies
Set "expires" field to balance freshness and caching (recommended: 30-90 days)
Provide contact information for policy questions
Consider cryptographic signatures for high-value content
Monitor access patterns and respond with HTTP 430 when violations detected
Document policy rationale in human-readable form (policy_uri)

section.title: For AI System Operators
section.t: AI systems SHOULD:

list.t: Fetch /.well-known/aibdp.json before initial content access
Parse and validate manifest structure
Respect declared boundaries or skip content if unable to comply
Cache manifests according to "expires" field
Verify signatures when present and validation is supported
Include User-Agent identifying system and purpose
Consider using consent headers (AI-Purpose, AI-Consent-Reviewed)
Log compliance decisions for audit purposes
Contact publishers via provided contact URI when clarification needed
